title-group.article-title: Synthesis and characterization of amphiphilic methoxypoly(ethylene glycol)-polystyrene diblock copolymer by ATRP and NMRP techniques

article-meta.aff: 1Laboratory of Chemistry Research, Payame Noor University, Tabriz, Iran
2Laboratory of Materials, Islamic Azad University, Bonab branch, Bonab, Iran
3Laboratory of Polymer, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Mojtaba Abbasian, Laboratory of Chemistry Research, Payame Noor University, Tabriz, Iran Email: m_abbasian20@yahoo.com

abstract.p: Amphiphilic block copolymers are used in a variety of applications, for example, as stabilizers for emulsions and dispersions or as compatibilizers in polymer blends. Amphiphilic diblock copolymer composed of methoxypoly(ethylene glycol) and polystyrene (MPEG-b-PS) was synthesized using atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP) and nitroxide-mediated radical polymerization (NMRP). In order to synthesize MPEG-b-PS diblock copolymer using ATRP, monofunctional MPEG macroinitiator (chloroacetylated MPEG [MPEG-Cl]) was prepared from monohydroxyfunctional poly(ethylene glycol) and initiated end group on the basis of chloroacetyl chloride. ATRP was carried out in bulk using MPEG-Cl as the macroinitiator, copper chloride (CuCl)/2,2′-bipyridine (bipy) as the catalyst ([MPEG-Cl]/[CuCl]/[bipy] = 1:1:3), and styrene as the monomer. For preparation of MPEG-b-PS by means of NMRP, firstly, 1-hydroxy-2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-piperidine (TEMPO-OH) was obtained by reduction of 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-piperidinyl-1-oxy (TEMPO) with sodium ascorbat. Then, TEMPO-OH was coupled with chloroacetylated MPEG (MPEG-Cl) to yield the macroinitiator MPEG terminated with a TEMPO unit (MPEG-CO-TEMPO). At last, MPEG-CO-TEMPO was further used to prepare the diblock copolymer MPEG-b-PS by ‘living’ free radical polymerization of styrene. The products were purified and identified by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), and gel permeation chromatography (GPC).

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Amphiphilic block copolymers are macromolecular compounds of great importance from both fundamental scientific and many technological point of views for a large variety of applications, for example, as stabilizers for emulsions and dispersions or as compatibilizers in polymer blends. 1 Design and synthesis of such a material with novel properties have attracted considerable attention on the aspect of polymer chemistry. 2 In particular, block copolymers composed of poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG)/poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO) and poly(propylene oxide) (PPO) have been extensively studied and the micellar phase structures were investigated. 3,4

Several publications have appeared in recent years concerning the preparation of poly(ethylene glycol) and polystyrene (PEG-b-PS) diblock copolymers with well-defined molecular structures. 5,6 The synthesis methods reported are mostly anionic polymerization processes including coupling reaction and sequential polymerization techniques. In addition, it has been reported that PS-b-PEG may be synthesized by conventional free radical polymerization, using a macroinitiator technique, 7,8 but the copolymer had a broad molecular weight distribution. Recent developments in living free radical polymerization have made it possible to control the polymerization to obtain polymers with predetermined molecular weights, narrow molecular weight distributions, and well-defined compositions. 9–11 Two major types of living free radical polymerization systems have been investigated, namely nitroxide-mediated radical polymerization (NMRP), in which the polymerization is controlled by reversible termination between propagating free radical and a stable nitroxyl radical most often 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-piperidinyl-1-oxy (TEMPO), 12–14 and atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP), where a transition metal compound acts as a carrier of a halogen atom in a reversible redox process. Copper-based ATRP has received a great deal of attention in the literature because of its monomer versatility and simplicity in practice. 15–17 ATRP is an efficient route for synthesizing polymers with well-controlled molecular weight and low polydispersity. 18 The fast and reversible equilibrium between growing radicals and dormants species results in a low and constant concentration of growing radicals, which, along with the fast initiation and negligible irreversible termination, enables the polymerization proceed in a living manner. 19 So far, ATRP has successfully been used to prepare a wide range of products with various chain architectures, such as liner, star, block star, dendritic, highly branched, comb architectures 20 and various compositions. 18 Also, NMRP was successfully used to synthesize several block, branch or star copolymers by subsequent multistep addition of a second monomer. 2

In this study, we synthesized an amphiphilic methoxypoly(ethylene glycol) and PS (MPEG-b-PS) diblock copolymer using the ATRP and NMRP techniques. We reported the preparation of an MPEG macroinitiator with a initiating end group based on chloroacetyl chloride ([CAC] chloroacetylated MPEG [MPEG-Cl]), which is subsequently used in the preparation of diblock copolymer MPEG-b-PS by heating with styrene in bulk under ATRP conditions; and in the case of NMRP, living free radical polymerization has been investigated for synthesizing MPEG-b-PS copolymer using the facile method concept of Georges et al. and the methodology developed by Hawker and Hedrick. 21 The synthesis was carried out by coupling of chloacetylated MPEG (MPEG-Cl) with TEMPO-OH to yield the macroinitiator MPEG terminated with a TEMPO unit (MPEG-CO-TEMPO).

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: CAC (90%, 1.42 kg/L), from Merck (Germany), was refluxed with thionyl chloride for about 2 h and then distilled. Before use, it was freshly distilled under vacuum at room temperature. Triethylamine (TEA) was refluxed with p-toluenesulfonyl chloride and distilled. The resulting amine-free TEA was stored on calcium hydride (CaH2). Before use, it was refluxed and distilled again. 4-(Dimethylamino) pyridine (DMAP) was recrystallized from toluene. Dichloromethane (CH2Cl2) was shaken with portions of concentrated H2SO4 until the acid layer remained colorless, then washed with water, aqueous 5% Na2HCO3 and with water again, and finally distilled from CaH2. Copper chloride ([CuCl] Merck) was washed with acetone several times until it became light yellow and was stored in a brown glass bottle. 22 Before use mono-MPEG with a molecular weight of 2000 (Merck) was dried by azeotropic distillation with toluene and the traces of residual toluene was removed under vacuum. Before use, styrene (Tabriz Petrochemical Co., Iran) was distilled under reduced pressure with CaH2. TEMPO was prepared by the method reported from our research group previously. 23 Tetrahydrofuran ([THF] Merck) was distilled with sodium/benzophenone. All other chemicals were purchased from Merck and purified according to the standard methods.

sec.title: Instrumentation
sec.p: Infrared (IR) spectra were measured with a Shimadzu model IR-408 spectrometer. The samples were prepared by grinding the dry powders with potassium bromide (KBr) and compressing the mixture to form disks. The disks were stored in a desiccator to avoid moisture absorption. Spectra were recorded at room temperature. 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded using Bruker 400 MHz Fourier transform (FT)-NMR spectrometer in deuterated chloroform (CDCl3). The molecular weight of the resulting polymer was obtained with a maxima 820 gel permeation chromatography (GPC) using the PS (106, 105, 104 A0) calibration standard with a THF mobile phase at a flow rate of 1 ml/min and column temperature of 30°C.

sec.title: Preparation of MPEG-Cl macroinitiator
sec.p: 0.0915 g (0.75 mmol) sample of 4-(Dimethylamino) pyridine (DMAP) in 2 ml of dry Dichloromethane (CH2Cl2) was mixed with 0.07 ml (0.5 mmol of triethylamine (TEA). The solution was transferred into a 250-ml three-neck round-bottom flask equipped with condenser, dropping funnel, gas inlet/outlet, and a magnetic stirrer. After cooling to 0°C, 0.1 ml (1.25 mmol) of CAC in 2 ml of CH2Cl2 was added. To the formed yellow dispersion 1 g of MPEG-2000 in 10 ml of dry CH2Cl2 was added dropwise during 1 h under dry N2. Subsequently the temperature was allowed to rise to room temperature and the reaction was continued under stirring for 18 h. The solution was filtered, half of the solvent was evaporated, and the MPEG macroinitiator was precipitated in cold diethylether. After dissolution in methanol, the solution was stored overnight to recrystallize the product. The macroinitiator was filtered, washed with cold ether, and dried in vacuum (Figure 1).

caption.p: Synthesis of chloroacetylated methoxypoly(ethylene glycol) (MPEG-Cl) macroinitiator.

sec.title: Reduction of TEMPO to TEMPO-OH
sec.p: TEMPO (1 g, 6.4 mmol) was suspended in a solution of sodium ascorbate (2.1 g, 10.6 mmol) in water (18 ml) and shaken vigorously until it was completely decolorized (ca. 0.5 h). The resulting suspension was extracted with ether. Afterward, the ether extracts were washed with water and brine, dried (sodium sulfate [Na2SO4]), and evaporated to give a crude product (Figure 2). The 1-hydroxy-2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-piperidine TEMPO-OH was characterized by FT-IR spectroscopy. 3250-3600 cm–1 (O-H bond), 2860-2972 cm–1 (−CH3 stretching bond). 24

sec.title: Preparation of nitroxide-mediated MPEG macroinitiator (MPEG-CO-TEMPO)
sec.p: In a two-neck round-bottom flask equipped with condenser, dropping funnel, gas inlet/outlet, and a magnetic stirrer; 0.05 g (0.32 mmol) of TEMPO-OH was dissolved in anhydrous N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (1 ml) and then added under N2 to 21.5 mg (0.89 mmol) NaH (hexane washed). The mixture was stirred for 0.5 h, then 1 g of MPEG-Cl-2000 mixed with 10 ml dry DMF was added dropwise under N2 and refluxed for 24 h. Excess NaH was destroyed by slow addition of methanol to the clear, red solution. To this mixture, 15 ml of diethylether were added at room temperature and then stirred in an ice bath. The solid was filtered and dried in vacuum (Figure 3).

sec.title: ATRP of styrene using the MPEG-Cl macroinitiator
sec.p: A glass tube was charged with 0.25 g (0.12 mmol) of MPEG-Cl macroinitiator, 0.012 g (0.12 mmol) of CuCl and 0.055 g (0.36 mmol) of bipyridine (bipy). Five milliliters (43.61 mmol) of styrene were added in ampoule degassed with several freeze-pump-thaw cycles, sealed off under vacuum and placed in an oil bath. The solution was stirred and heated at 90°C under N2. After 14 h, the crude product was dissolved in dichloromethane and then was filtrated and solution was precipitated into acidified 80% methanol (v/v 1000 ml; 15 ml of HCl). At the end of the reaction, the reaction mixture was dissolved in carbon tetrachloride (CCl4) and stirred in air, until the copper catalyst was completely oxidized. The resulting copper (II) complex is insoluble in the polymer solution and is easily removed by filtration. The solvent and the monomer still present in the filtrate were then evaporated and the product was reprecipitated in methanol and dried to constant weight. The molecular weight and the molecular weight distribution of the obtained product were determined by GPC and the structure of the product was determined by 1 H NMR spectroscopy. The crude product was dried under vacuum and weighed (3.2 g, yield: 72%). The reaction scheme for ATRP of styrene using MPEG-Cl as the macroinitiator is shown in Figure 4.

caption.p: Preparation of methoxypoly(ethylene glycol) and polystyrene (MPEG-b-PS) diblock copolymer using chloroacetylated methoxypoly(ethylene glycol) (MPEG-Cl) macroinitiator.

sec.title: NMRP of styrene using MPEG-CO-TEMPO macroinitiator
sec.p: 0.4 g of macroinitiator (MPEG-CO-TEMPO) and 5 ml (43.61 mmol) of styrene was placed in ampoule degassed with several freeze-pump-thaw cycles, sealed off under vacuum and placed in an oil bath. The solution was stirred and heated at 125°C. During the reaction, it was observed that the viscosity of the solution gradually increased. After 14 h, the solution was dissolved in 10 ml CH2Cl2 and precipitated in 50 ml hexane for 24 h and reprecipitated in CH2Cl2 in 50 ml methanol. The crude product was dried in vacuum and weighed (yield: 3.43 g, 70%). The reaction scheme for NMRP of styrene using MPEG-CO-TEMPO as the macroinitiator is shown in Figure 5.

caption.p: Preparation of methoxypoly(ethylene glycol) and polystyrene (MPEG-b-PS) diblock copolymer using 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-piperidinyl-1-oxy-terminated MPEG (MPEG-CO-TEMPO) macroinitiator.

sec.title: Purification of diblock copolymers
sec.p: The structural evidence for the existence of block copolymer MPEG-b-PS was given by selective extraction of the copolymer with water and cyclohexane by reductive cleavage of the ester bond between the two blocks, separation of the resulting polystyrene from mono-MPEG, and subsequent analysis of the resulting blocks as reported earlier. 25

The extraction of the diblock copolymer with water and cyclohexane was carried out in order to remove MPEG homopolymer from the diblock copolymers (if present in the crude product because of incomplete functionalisation of hydroxyl-MPEG or due to combination reactions in the early phases of the polymerization) and to remove possible polystyrene homopolymer formed by thermal polymerization. Thus, the crude product was extracted with cyclohexane at room temperature 3 times for 3 days. The residue was purified (after drying and weighing) by extracting twice with distilled water at room temperature in order to remove the possible unreacted MPEG macroinitiator. The purified product was dried in vacuum and weighed. In synthesizing MPEG-b-PS by NMRP, the yield of 65% of crude product was reduced to only 40% after purification. A large amount of homopolystyrene was produced which was isolated by 1 H NMR spectrum. The 72% yield of MPEG-b-PS obtained by ATRP was reduced to only 67% after purification.

sec.title: ATRP of styrene using MPEG-Cl macroinitiator
sec.p: In the first step of the synthesis of MPEG-b-PS diblock copolymer (Figure 1), the macroinitiator is prepared by reacting MPEG with chloroacetyl chloride. In order to avoid the cleavage of the MPEG polymer chains, as found in case of other derivatizations of PEG, 26 the reaction was carried out at 0°C in THF in the presence of TEA and DMAP.

The IR spectrum of MPEG-2000 and FT-IR spectrum of MPEG-Cl are shown in Figure 6a, b. The strong absorption at 3300–3400 cm−1, which is the characteristic of the –OH end group of MPEG, disappeared completely in the spectrum of the macroinitiator and the absorption at 1752 cm−1 was for the –CO– group, which indicated the transformation of the end group of MPEG. 27

caption.p: (a) Infrared (IR) spectrum of methoxypoly(ethylene glycol) (MPEG)-2000 and (b) Fourier transform IR (FT-IR) spectrum of chloroacetylated MPEG (MPEG-Cl) macroinitiator.

sec.p: The complete substitution of the hydroxyl group was also proved by 1 H NMR spectroscopy. The OH signal of MPEG around 2.69 ppm (Figure 7a) had disappeared after the esterification and two new signals appeared at 4.08 and 4.3 ppm, due to the substituted MPEG (Figure 7a, b) for the methylene protons next to the ester oxygen and chlorine, respectively.

caption.p: (a) 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrum of methoxypoly(ethylene glycol) (MPEG)-2000 and (b) chloroacetylated MPEG (MPEG-Cl) macroinitiator.

sec.p: The yield of the MPEG-Cl macroinitiator produced could be calculated with 1 H NMR data, according to the following equation:

where Ia and Id are the integral values of the peaks at 4.3 and 3.34 ppm, respectively, belonging to methylene protons next to the chlorine and methyl protons. The a:d integration ratio is 1.8:3 and the theoretical number is 2:3, supporting the fact that the chlorine was not lost during the propagation reactions. For approve of Quantitative ester substitution, a small amount of the starting MPEG, was added to the solution of chloroacetylated MPEG in a NMR tube, whereupon the signal at 2.69 ppm was represented.

ATRP of styrene in bulk using MPEG-Cl macroinitiator was carried out at 90°C, with a molar ratio of initiator/CuCl/bipy of 1:1:3. Figure 8 indicates the 1 H NMR spectrum of MPEG-b-PS. A single peak at 3.65 ppm existed both in the macroinitiator and in the diblock copolymer for the methylene group of MPEG, but for the diblock copolymer new signals appeared at 1.43–1.84 and 6.3–7.4 ppm, respectively, due to the characteristic resonance of aliphatic protons in PS (signal [b]) and benzene ring (signal [a]) in PS units.

caption.p: 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrum of methoxypoly(ethylene glycol) and polystyrene (MPEG-b-PS) copolymer.

sec.p: The 1 H NMR spectrum provides strong evidence for the presence of both MPEG and PS segments in the polymer chain. The composition of the diblock copolymer was determined by 1 H NMR spectroscopy from the integral ratio of the signals originated from the PS block at 6.3–7.4 ppm (signal [b], 5H, C6H5) and from the MPEG-Cl region (signal [d], 4H, –CH2–CH2–) according to the following equation:

Where Ia and Id are the integral of the signals originated from the PS block at 6.3–7.4 ppm and the MPEG block at 3.65 ppm; 104 and 44 are the molar masses of styrene and –CH2–CH2–O repeat unit in MPEG segment, respectively, and f st is the mass fraction of styrene in the corresponding MPEG-b-PS diblock copolymer. The average molecular weights of the corresponding MPEG-b-PS diblock copolymer were calculated from f st and M n and estimated by 1 H NMR analysis of MPEG-Cl, which is shown in Table 1.

caption.p: GPC and NMR data of MPEG-b-PS diblock copolymers and their precursors

fn.p: GPC: gel permeation chromatography, MPEG: methoxypoly(ethylene glycol), MPEG-b-PS: methoxypoly(ethylene glycol) and polystyrene, MPEG-Cl: chloroacetylated MPEG, MPEG-CO-TEMPO: TEMPO-terminated MPEG-Cl, NMR: nuclear magnetic resonance, TEMPO: 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-piperidinyl-1-oxy.
a The measured M n of the MPEG-b-PS diblock copolymers by GPC.
b M n estimated by NMR analysis of MPEG-b-PS.
c Weight fraction of PS and MPEG in the copolymers determined by 1 H NMR spectroscopy.

sec.p: It was found that the synthesis of the MPEG-Cl macroinitiator by GPC analysis involved no reduction in molecular weight because narrow symmetrical signal was observed essentially at the same position at the starting MPEG. Figure 9 represents the GPCs of the macroinitiator (Figure 9a) and the product (Figure 9b) whose molecular weight distributions are 1.03 and 1.21.

caption.p: (a) Gel permeation chromatography (GPC) curves of chloroacetylated methoxypoly(ethylene glycol) (MPEG-Cl) macroinitiator and (b) MPEG and polystyrene (MPEG-b-PS) copolymer.

sec.p: An increase in molecular weight from M n = 2878 to 14,578 supports the formation of diblock copolymer. This indicates the involvement of essentially all the MPEG macroinitiator chains in initiating the ATRP of styrene. Also, the diblock obtained has narrow M w/M n values (M w/M n = 1.21) for MPEG-Cl macroinitiator, which further indicates a high efficiency of the macroinitiator and a low degree of uncontrolled polymerization generated by side reaction particularly thermal polymerization.

sec.title: NMRP of styrene using MPEG-CO-TEMPO macroinitiator
sec.p: To prepare MPEG-b-PS diblock copolymer using NMRP technique, the macroinitiator MPEG-CO-TEMPO was prepared by reacting TEMPO-OH with MPEG-Cl. The FT-IR spectra of MPEG-CO-TEMPO macroinitiator demonstrate an absorption bond at 1480 cm−1 which is attributed to methyl bond of TEMPO. 28 Also, the absorption bonds at 2885 and 1110 cm−1 are attributed to C–H and C–O bond of MPEG, respectively. The absorption at 1620 cm−1 was for the –CO– group. The stretching bond of C–N and N–O of TEMPO is absent in FT-IR spectra of macroinitiator because these peaks overlap with the peaks of MPEG (Figure 10).

caption.p: Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrum of 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-piperidinyl-1-oxy-terminated methoxypoly(ethylene glycol) (MPEG-CO-TEMPO) macroinitiator.

sec.p: Figure 11 represents the 1 H NMR spectra of MPEG-CO-TEMPO macroinitiator. The functional group TEMPO appears with characteristic signals at 0.87–1.24 ppm.

caption.p: 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrum of macroinitiator 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-piperidinyl-1-oxy-terminated methoxypoly(ethylene glycol) (MPEG-CO-TEMPO).

sec.p: The thermal homolytic scission of the C–O bond of the aminoxy moiety of the MPEG-CO-TEMPO occurred at 125°C and caused radical polymerization of styrene to yield the amphiphilic diblock copolymer MPEG-b-PS, as shown in Figure 5. The bond dissociation is considered reversible. In the TEMPO-mediated polymerization of styrene, it has been found that the polymerization is driven by a constant supply of initiating radicals by thermal initiation to make up for the irreversible termination reactions, while the adduct with TEMPO controls the molecular weight and polydispersities by exchange reactions. 29 The crude polymerization product was purified as described in the section on Experimental. The 70% yield of crude product was reduced to 40% after purification. A large amount of homopolystyrene was produced which was isolated and identified by its 1 H NMR spectrum. Thermal polymerization along with nitroxide free radical-mediated polymerization of styrene and the factors affecting alkoxyamine homolysis rates have been reported. 30 In the purification of the crude product, unreacted macroinitiator as well as water soluble MPEG-b-PS with short polystyrene segments was identified in the reaction mixture. This observation is consistent with that reported by Jankova et al. 3

Figure 12 represents the 1 H NMR spectra of MPEG-b-PS. A single peak at 3.65 ppm existed both in the macroinitiator and in the diblock copolymer for the methylene group of MPEG, but for the diblock copolymer new signals have appeared at 1.43–1.84 and 6.64–7.05 ppm for the aliphatic protons in PS (signal [b]) and phenyl ring protons (signal [c]) in PS units, respectively. The 1 H NMR spectra confirmed the coexistence of the PS chain and the MPEG chain in the macroinitiator structure.

caption.p: 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrum of methoxypoly(ethylene glycol) and polystyrene (MPEG-b-PS) copolymer.

sec.p: The composition of the diblock copolymer was determined by 1 H NMR spectroscopy from the integral ratio of the signals originated from the PS block at 6.64–7.05 ppm (signal [c], 5H, C6H5) and from the MPEG region (signal [d], 4H, –CH2–CH2–), according to Eq. (1), as follows:

where I c and I d are the integral of the signals originated from the PS block at 6.64–7.05 ppm and the MPEG block at 3.65 ppm. The average molecular weight of the corresponding MPEG-b-PS diblock copolymer is shown in Table 1.

Figure 13 represents the GPCs of the macroinitiator (Figure 13a) and the product (Figure 13b) whose molecular weight distributions are 1.24 and 1.28, respectively. The GPC curves indicate that MPEG-b-PS diblock copolymer is formed, since the elution curve is shifted toward higher molecular weight (from Mn = 2873 to 7845). The single peak of the GPC curve indicated that the product could not be a blend of PS and MPEG homopolymers.

caption.p: (a) Gel permeation chromatography (GPC) curves of 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-piperidinyl-1-oxy-terminated methoxypoly(ethylene glycol) (MPEG-CO-TEMPO) macroinitiator and (b) methoxypoly(ethylene glycol) and polystyrene (MPEG-b-PS) copolymer.

sec.p: Table 1 presents the molecular weights, molecular weight distributions of the MPEG, MPEG-Cl macroinitiator, MPEG-CO-TEMPO macroinitiator, and MPEG-b-PS diblock copolymers. The composition (block length and MPEG content in weight) of the diblock copolymers are also shown in Table 1.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Amphiphilic MPEG-b-PS diblock copolymer have been synthesized by ATRP technique using MPEG-Cl as the macroinitiator, and NMRP technique using MPEG-CO-TEMPO as the macroinitiator. MPEG-Cl macroinitiator was prepared by the transformation of the end group of the MPEG by CAC, and the MPEG-CO-TEMPO macroinitiator by reacting MPEG-Cl with TEMPO-OH obtained by reduction of TEMPO. It has been demonstrated that MPEG-Cl and TEMPO terminated MPEG-Cl initiate living free radical polymerization of styrene to yield amphiphilic diblock copolymer MPEG-b-PS. The formation of the diblock copolymers was supported by GPC, 1 H NMR, and IR spectroscopic analyses.

ack.p: The authors express their gratitude to the Tabriz Payame Noor University and ‘Bonyade Melli Nokhbeghan Institute’ for supporting this project.
